channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Leeds heart surgery data 'wrong'
item.description: Children's heart surgery was wrongly suspended at Leeds General Infirmary because of "incomplete" information, a senior doctor says.

item.title: NUT calls for Ofsted chief to resign
item.description: The National Union of Teachers (NUT) calls for the resignation of Ofsted chief inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw over claims he is demoralising teachers.

item.title: Mandela breathing without difficulty
item.description: Nelson Mandela is breathing without difficulty in hospital, the South African presidency says, after excess fluid in his lungs was drained.

item.title: N Korea in 'state of war' with South
item.description: North Korea says it is entering a "state of war" with South Korea, in the latest escalation of rhetoric against its neighbour and the US.

item.title: Kenya court upholds Kenyatta win
item.description: Kenya's Supreme Court upholds Uhuru Kenyatta's first round presidential election victory, rejecting several petitions challenging the vote.

item.title: Post Office staff go on strike
item.description: Thousands of staff at Post Office Crown offices go on strike in a row over jobs, pay and branch closures.

item.title: Climber dies in 100ft Snowdonia fall
item.description: An ice climber dies after falling 100ft (30m) from a frozen mountain in Snowdonia, while two walkers are rescued in a separate incident.

item.title: Karzai heads to Qatar for talks
item.description: Afghan President Karzai travels to Qatar, with the possible opening of a Taliban office in the Gulf state expected to be on the agenda,

item.title: NZ cricketer Ryder out of coma
item.description: New Zealand cricketer Jesse Ryder has come out of a medically-induced coma, three days after he was attacked outside a bar in Christchurch.

item.title: Call for higher tax on second homes
item.description: The head of the Campaign to Protect Rural England says the tax system should be used to put countryside second homes beyond the reach of more people.

item.title: Tennant to make Doctor Who return
item.description: David Tennant and Billie Piper will appear in the 50th anniversary special of Doctor Who, the BBC confirms.

item.title: Easter egg 'hotter than a vindaloo'
item.description: An Indian restaurant in Surrey creates a "not for bunnies" Easter egg using three of the hottest varieties of chillies.

item.title: Poachers threaten wildlife parks
item.description: Wildlife parks increase night-time patrols after a warning from Kent police poachers may target their rare black rhinos.

item.title: Sunderland 0-1 Man Utd
item.description: Manchester United edge closer to the Premier League title and further deepen Sunderland's relegation fears.

item.title: Wilkinson to play on next season
item.description: Former England international Jonny Wilkinson is set to play on for another season with Toulon after considering retirement.

item.title: Murray sees off Gasquet in semis
item.description: Britain's Andy Murray beats Richard Gasquet in three sets and will face David Ferrer in the Sony Open final in Miami on Sunday.

item.title: Boat Race basics
item.description: The fastest, the heaviest, the most successful, the sinkings - BBC Sport gives you the lowdown on Oxford v Cambridge

item.title: Jockey McNamara paralysed after fall
item.description: Jockey JT McNamara remains positive despite being paralysed by a neck injury sustained in a fall at the Cheltenham Festival.

item.title: Tough Bank of Cyprus terms detailed
item.description: Officials spell out the tough Bank of Cyprus "haircut" that depositors holding more than 100,000 euros must take as part of an EU-IMF bailout.

item.title: Camera chain Jessops re-launches
item.description: Camera chain Jessops has re-opened two of its stores just a couple of months after going into administration in January with the closure of 187 branches

item.title: PM marginalising Christians - Carey
item.description: The former archbishop of Canterbury, Lord Carey, accuses David Cameron of increasing the anxieties of Christians who want to practise their faith.

item.title: Victims' Code criticised by watchdog
item.description: Victims of crime are being put under extreme duress, leading to injustices, due to a lack of awareness of the Victims' Code by those working in the justice system, a watchdog warns.

item.title: Cancer survivors deserve 'care plan'
item.description: All cancer patients should receive a 'recovery package' at the end of their treatment offering ongoing support, the government has announced.

item.title: Heart patients 'helped by vest'
item.description: Doctors in London have been using special vests to help diagnose abnormal heart rhythms, in the first UK test of its kind.

item.title: Teachers urge parents to back action
item.description: The NUT says it will hold public rallies to gather the support of parents in its campaign against government policies in schools.

item.title: University protesters to be evicted
item.description: The High Court rules that protesters should be evicted from part of the University of Sussex.

item.title: Amazon buys book recommendation site
item.description: Online retailer Amazon says it will buy a book discovery and recommendation website Goodreads, which has 16 million members.

item.title: Blackberry reports 1m Z10 sales
item.description: Mobile phone maker Blackberry says it sold one million of its new Z10 smartphones, but has lost three million users.

item.title: Cash shortage stretches to sea bed
item.description: The government admits going slowly on protecting wildlife in the seas because of the costs involved.

item.title: Met Office advice was 'not helpful'
item.description: The Met Office has admitted issuing "unhelpful" advice to government during last year's remarkable switch in weather patterns.

item.title: Actor Richard Griffiths dies aged 65
item.description: Actor Richard Griffiths, star of the Harry Potter movies and Withnail and I, dies after complications following heart surgery at the age of 65.

item.title: Obituary: Richard Griffiths
item.description: DIGIONLY

item.title: The rise of chocolate purism
item.description: You can now buy 100% cocoa chocolate on the High Street, but does "real" chocolate have to be high in cocoa?

item.title: Quiz of the week's news
item.description: The Magazine's weekly quiz of the news, 7 days 7 questions.

item.title: Woman charged after girl found
item.description: A woman is charged with child neglect after a two-year-old girl is found in a pram in Cumbria.

item.title: Police watchdog probes custody death
item.description: The Independent Police Complaints Commission confirms it is investigating the death of a 43-year-old man in Northumbria Police custody

item.title: Opponents of 'bedroom tax' protest
item.description: Thousands of people demonstrate against changes to the benefits system which have been described as a "bedroom tax".

item.title: Christian Church opens doors to Muslims
item.description: An Episcopal church in Aberdeen is opened to hundreds of Muslim worshippers for their daily prayers.

item.title: Pipe bomb explodes outside house
item.description: A pipe bomb has exploded after being thrown at a house in the village of Bessbrook in County Armagh.

item.title: Air support goes in relief effort
item.description: All air support has now been withdrawn from the relief operation to animals stranded in the snow in Northern Ireland.

item.title: Help for snow-hit sheep farmers
item.description: Easing pressure on farmers in north and mid Wales suffering with the loss of livestock after heavy snow is an "urgent priority" says the Welsh government.

item.title: Saints confirm offer for North
item.description: Northampton are giving Wales wing George North 'time and space' to consider a move from Scarlets to Franklin's Gardens.

item.title: Tanzania collapse 'leaves 17 dead'
item.description: At least 17 people are killed after a multi-storey building collapses in the main Tanzanian city, Dar es Salaam, local officials say.

item.title: Xi wraps up Africa trip in Congo
item.description: China's President Xi Jinping seals a string of deals and promises to boost ties further as he ends a week-long trip to Africa in the Republic of Congo.

item.title: Hopes fade for Tibet buried miners
item.description: The chances of finding survivors following a landslide in Tibet that buried 83 miners are slim, Chinese media report.

item.title: Musharraf bail extended amid chaos
item.description: A court in Pakistan extends bail for former President Pervez Musharraf, amid chaotic scenes in which a shoe is thrown at him.

item.title: 'Select group' to end Italy impasse
item.description: Italian President Giorgio Napolitano says he will ask a select group of people to advise on ending an impasse in forming a new government.

item.title: Pope leads Good Friday services
item.description: Pope Francis leads services to mark Good Friday as part of the Easter triduum, the Roman Catholic Church's most important festival.

item.title: Tear gas at Brazil World Cup stadium
item.description: Police in Brazil uses tear gas and smoke grenades to break up clashes outside stadium built for the 2014 World Cup while other venues are still unfinished.

item.title: Students and police clash in Chile
item.description: Thousands of Chilean students clash with police on the streets of the capital, Santiago, during a protest calling for education reforms.

item.title: Car bombs hit Iraqi worshippers
item.description: A series of car bomb attacks in Baghdad and Kirkuk have targeted Shia mosques during Friday prayers, killing at least 19 people.

item.title: Libyans held for Briton 'sex attack'
item.description: Two Libyans are arrested over claims they sexually assaulted two British aid workers near the eastern city of Benghazi, officials say.

item.title: Obama promotes infrastructure plan
item.description: US President Barack Obama appeals for increased private investment in infrastructure, saying it will create jobs and boost the US economy.

item.title: 'HIV risk' for US dentist's patients
item.description: Health officials in the US state of Oklahoma warn 7,000 patients their dentist may have exposed them to HIV and hepatitis, urging them to get tested.

item.title: Mozambique: Life in pictures
item.description: Ariadne Van Zandbergen explores this changing country

item.title: Your pictures: On the edge
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme On the edge

item.title: Day in pictures: 27 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 27 March

item.title: In pictures: Losing Ground
item.description: Communities in Cambodia fight for their right to land

item.title: Day in pictures: 26 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 26 March

item.title: In pictures: Shifting Perspectives
item.description: Representation of people with Down’s syndrome

item.title: Day in pictures: 25 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 25 March

item.title: In Pictures: Rowena Cade's theatre
item.description: The Minack Theatre prepares for its new season

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The health secretary has set out the government's response to the Stafford Hospital inquiry.

item.title: VIDEO: Winnie 'humbled' by Mandela well-wishers
item.description: Winnie Mandela has said she is "extremely touched" by the concern shown over the health of her ex-husband Nelson Mandela, who is spending a third day in a South African hospital with a lung infection.

item.title: VIDEO: Tanzania collapse 'traps dozens'
item.description: At least three people have been killed and dozens are missing after a multi-storey building collapsed in the Tanzanian commercial capital, Dar es Salaam.

item.title: VIDEO: Latvian fishermen stranded on ice
item.description: Latvian rescue services have picked up dozens of people trapped on ice floes that wind drove out to the Bay of Riga.

item.title: VIDEO: Pope Francis leads Good Friday rite
item.description: Pope Francis is presiding over Easter services for the first time as the head of the Catholic Church.

item.title: VIDEO: Spacecraft shortens trip to ISS
item.description: A Soyuz space capsule has docked at the International Space Station (ISS) after a journey of less than six hours.

item.title: VIDEO: Swimmers brave snow for dip in lake
item.description: Snowfall and near freezing temperatures did not deter a group of hardy Germans who braved the conditions to open Berlin's bathing season at the Wannsee lake.

item.title: VIDEO: Fish market gets 'seal' of approval
item.description: More than 150 species of fish and shellfish from all over the world are sold at Billingsgate Market in London but a seal, nicknamed Sammy by porters, prefers to be fed salmon.

item.title: AUDIO: Actor Griffiths on playing Uncle Monty
item.description: Actor Richard Griffiths, who starred in the Harry Potter movies and Withnail and I, has died at the age of 65 after complications following heart surgery.

item.title: Fortnight of fear
item.description: Filling the school holiday void with a son with autism

item.title: The speeches written but never given
item.description: Those speeches written but never given

item.title: Does chocolate give you spots?
item.description: Does gorging on chocolate give you spots?

item.title: Week in pictures: 23-29 March 2013
item.description: A selection of news photographs from around the world this week

item.title: Do we need a new type of phone bill?
item.description: Do people understand their mobile phone bills?

item.title: VIDEO: Five Minutes With: Sir John Eliot Gardiner
item.description: Sir John Eliot Gardiner on conducting and being a farmer

item.title: Cyprus: Clouds of uncertainty over island
item.description: Paul Mason watches the banks reopen in Cyprus
